title: What’s the difference between art rock and progressive rock? - Quora

response.answer_text: So here’s the secret of how genres are worked out. In record shops, they used to put similar kinds of music together, so that you didn’t have to browse through the Mantovani to get to the Metallica. Those distinctions were called genres. They had to call them something, so they got vaguely descriptive names, like pop, rock, jazz, blues. Now there’s so much music that even narrowing it to that level isn’t enough, so we have an ever lengthening list of sub-genres that are supposed to distinguish between the slightest nuances of style between one artist and the next. Fandom being what it is, there are always plenty of numpties ready to argue that this or that album isn’t ‘proper’ bebop, or whatever. This is particularly true in the niche markets, where fans (for deep-seated but inexplicable psychological reasons) feel a personal proprietorial ownership of the music, as part of their own identity, and get disappointed if it goes mainstream. By this point the record shops have lost interest; they certainly aren’t going to create a special sales area for the two records on issue which can be defined as ‘acid grime’ or whatever the latest thin slice of music has been called. But the music buying world is now so obsessed with these arbitrary and finely-cut distinctions that a particularly creative artist might, in the course of one album, produce work in several different ‘genres’. The truth is that the difference between art rock and progressive rock is whatever you want it to be, or if you don’t want it to be, then it doesn’t exist; there is no difference. It’s just music.

There’s a lot of similarity. I’m not sure how important it is to try to make too fine grained distinctions. I’m sure many bands / artists can be considered both. But Progressive rock tends to put more of its artistic emphasis on the music itself : maybe longer, more elaborate arrangements with different sections in different styles. Art rock may do that but might also be content with fairly ordinary song-structures but given an aesthetic twist because of a new instrument, or lyrical trick or even just the style of presentation. I may be off here, but take someone like David Bowie. He’s clearly very “art”, from the costumes / personas, style, musical experimentation, deep cultural interest etc. I think putting him in an “art rock” category would make a lot of sense. But he’s not really very “prog”. Most of his songs follow fairly typical verse / bridge / chorus structures. They’re well crafted and catchy pop/rock. But not musically elaborate or bringing layers of complexity.
